awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Advancements in Spatio-temporal Modeling and Education in Support of NEON and Large-scale and Long-term Ecological Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The scientific community is moving into an era where open-access data-rich environments provide extraordinary opportunities to understand the spatial and temporal complexity of ecological processes at regional to continental scales. Investment to collect, develop, and distribute data and tools to further large-scale and long-term science is exemplified by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) and Data Observation Network for Earth (DataONE) initiatives. These, and similar initiatives, represent a paradigm shift in the way future scientific discovery will occur. This Career award will develop theoretical, methodological, software, and instructional advancements that will allow current and future scientists and educators to draw valid inference about large and complex ecological systems by: assimilating disparate sources and types of data; accommodating spatial and temporal dependence to satisfy statistical model assumptions and improve predictive inference; partitioning and propagating sources of uncertainty through fine spatial scale predictions over large domains, and; scaling to effectively exploit information in massive datasets. The research will develop new flexible spatio-temporal modeling frameworks tailored to enable assessment of NEON's Grand Challenges in the areas of climate change, land use, invasive species, biogeochemistry, biodiversity, ecohydrology, and infectious diseases. Although development of the proposed methods is motivated by substantive questions related to NEON's mission, potential advancements in spatio-temporal data modeling will find use in fields such as public and environmental health, meteorology, engineering, and geosciences where the fundamental goal is the same -- use new findings to help improve society.


The proposed educational objectives will enable students to explore their particular research interests, exploit complex data to build new understanding, and learn to collaborate to address challenges and opportunities within and across their respective disciplines. The award will develop and deliver several integrative education activities including: i) the development and implementation of cross-college undergraduate and graduate degree programs in Geo- and Eco-Informatics; ii) an undergraduate senior-level course in applied environmental data modeling; iii) a graduate-level course focused on more advanced topics in hierarchical Bayesian spatio-temporal modeling; iv) enrichment of science instruction in 23 K-12 schools in 13 districts in southwestern Michigan, and; v) graduate research symposia focused on contemporary topics in environmental data analysis that will engage students and experts from multiple institutions and serve as an opportunity for the graduates to share their research, network, garner specialized skills, and learn about NEON data products. Education activities will allow future and current scientists to extend themselves in innovative ways and collaborate on problems.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on theoretical, methodological, software, and instructional advancements to allow current and future practitioners to better understand and manage large and complex ecological systems. These advancements were delivered in the form of new statistical theory, accompanying software, and workshops aimed at: combining multiple sources and types of data; using data collected over space and time in a way that satisfies important statistical rules; acknowledging sources of uncertainty in predictions, and; gleaning important information from massive and messy data. 

Although project goals were motivated by substantive questions related to the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) mission, a focus on advancing new more robust methods and implementing these methods in software, rather than on specific data types, allows results to be applied in a range of fields such as public and environmental health, meteorology, engineering, and geosciences. These and related fields are awash in data collected over space and time (referred to as spatial-temporal data) and, like the environmental and ecological fields, are facing challenges in extracting information from "Big Data."

A key result of this work is the development and application of new statistical methods and software to analyze big spatial-temporal data sets. These statistical methods are implemented in two open-source R packages called spBayes and spNNGP, and documented in over a dozen peer reviewed publications. As a proxy for general use since the beginning of the project, spBayes and spNNGP have been downloaded 98,215 and 17,849, respectively (according to The Comprehensive R Archive Network download logs). The statistical theory and efficient algorithms implemented in these packages allow researchers and practitioners to draw unprecedented inference from large spatial-temporal datasets, the scale of which was infeasible only a few years ago. 

In addition to developing methods and software for modeling large spatial-temporal data sets, substantial effort was directed to developing software for researchers and practitioners to more easily quantify forest health and demographic trends using complex, continental-scale, forest monitoring databases. The result of this effort is a new open-source R package called rFIA (https://rfia.netlify.app), that allows users to more fully unlock the information in the USDA Forest Service Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) database. Designed to accommodate a wide range of user objectives, rFIA simplifies the estimation of forest variables from the FIA database and allows users (experts and newcomers alike) to unlock the flexibility inherent to the Enhanced FIA design. The software is already extensively used by state, federal, and private forest industry groups (downloaded 13,155 times from Comprehensive R Archive Network since its release in October 2019). Initial analyses using rFIA, detailed in a recent Nature Communications paper, represent one of the first large-scale studies of tree population performance to be conducted in temperate forests. Results from this study provide an early warning of widespread shifts in forest composition and declining forest health across the western United States, with over half of the most abundant tree species in the region having undergone significant population decline in the last two decades. Large-scale shifts in spatial distribution were apparent for all species examined, driven in part by recent changes in forest disturbance regimes and long-term climate patterns.

Over the course of this project, the PI published 53 peer reviewed papers focused on model theory and application. Collectively, two of the more influential papers on modeling large spatial-temporal data sets, have been cited more than 500 times---a number anticipated to grow as these methods continue to find use in various applications. 

Education and outreach efforts focused on delivering short courses to graduate students and practitioners. The Annual Graduate Workshop on Environmental Data Analytics (GWEDA) was offered for four years at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) in Boulder, CO. This annual, week-long, workshop series hosted more than 100 graduate students from a range of fields who were interested in learning about modeling of big spatial-temporal data. In addition to the GWEDA, the project supported 12 other workshops that introduced undergraduate and graduate students to various topics in environmental data modeling.

As the scientific community moves into this data rich era, there is unprecedented opportunity to better understand the impacts of changing environments. Although the modeling tools developed through this project were motivated by substantive questions in terrestrial ecosystems, they will have far-reaching impact in fields such as public and environmental health, meteorology, engineering, and geosciences where the fundamental goal is to use new findings to help improve society.

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2021
Modified by: Andrew O Finley
